name: 非虛構：紀實創作
description: Creative nonfiction are true stories that employ literary and creative techniques for storytelling. It is a genre found in print and radio/audio journalism, sometimes under other names such as feature reporting, narrative nonfiction, long form, investigative reporting, science writing, cultural criticism (reviews), personal essays, profiles, documentary feature, etc. You may have encountered them in your daily consumption of “content” and “information.” Yet, creative nonfiction is a form that aims to convey vivid human experiences and knowledge with a viewpoint.
goals: To raise awareness of the progressive potential of media forms and technologies in globally connected societies.
To become a critical media commentator and agenda initiator of contemporary issues and causes.
Give the students hands-on experience to develop and report their own story in either print or audio form.
syllabus:
I am teaching this course—ona trial basis—partly because storytelling/writing is what got me intojournalism and communication in the first place. Training in qualitativeresearch further allowed me to work creatively with research material so thatthe human experience and interpretations can be told in an accessible way.Though it may be a luxury, composing compelling stories and making researchmaterial accessible to non-specialized audiences were the driving forces behindthis course.

**Course Requirement and Grading Policy**

  

We learn in this class by reading nonfictionstories, listening to podcasts, reading and listening to writers and producerssharing tips on writing and reporting, and analyzing the crafts ofstorytelling. Please be noted that all discussion and writing exercises will bein English. The final story output can be in Chinese or English.

**Where to Get the Readings and Podcasts?**

  

Consult the Resource List (end of thissyllabus) for assignments that require you to select your own stories to readand listen. I highly recommend getting the app, Podcasts, and subscribeto/search some of the shows for easy listening. I chose stories and podcastshows from contemporary magazines, public radio and other long-form, literaryjournalism. Other required readings, which will be placed in a folder for thisclass, are drawn from the following books:

_Now Write! Nonfiction: Memoir, Journalism, andCreative Nonfiction—Exercises from Today’s Best Writers and Teachers_ (Ed. Sherry Ellis, 2009, Penguin).

_True Stories, Well Told—from the first 20 years ofcreative nonfiction magazine._ (Ed.Lee Gutkind and Hattie Fletcher, 2014).

_Telling True Stories: A nonfiction writer’s guidefrom the Nieman Foundation at_

_Harvard University_ (Ed. Mark Kramer and Wendy Call, 2007, Plume).
